author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Anyone who has experience with something like Plug in Alliance Paul Frindle’s DSM will know that it’s excellent at high mid and high frequency manipulation but at 16 bands has almost no low end resolution

Soothe has (according to a post from the developer) 4096 bins in Normal Resolution Mode. This accounts for it’s (to me) generally very blurry sound, but that can be very useful in certain contexts and if used with care in the higher octaves can be a very worthwhile tradeoff

K, won’t be around for follow up questions today but tag me and I’ll reply tomorrow

author: cian riordan
content: Something to chew on: bass instruments, kick drums, et all — they’re not defined by the low end, they’re defined by the midrange and high end. They’re just supported by the low end.

author: cian riordan
content: Had a fun moment today where I'm mixing this retro-ey sounding tune for a band and I was really struggling to get the rhythm section to lock in and feel really warm and pillowy. I did a number on the drums but just couldn't get the low end to sync between the two. I ended up sending the mono bass to two mis-matched outboard compressors. They're totally un-linked and I just matched them by ear and wow... sounds so fucking good. Each one is grabbing and doing it's thing and it's *mostly* adding up to mono but gives real life when things momentarily lean left or right. Reminds me of a drum setup photo today where some of the mics were mis-matched and that's just honest-to-god so OK most of the time.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So there’s an old saying: if you wanna really know something, you gotta learn it, you gotta do it, then you gotta teach it. 

My friend who mentioned wanting to learn how to mix yesterday was amazed at how fast I was able to make his track sound big and loud and open all at the same time. “My mix sounded so small and congested. Yours sounds huge.”


Basically what I did, besides level & panning, was carve out a bunch of like 400 in all harmonic elements. All the tracks sounded good, but the density was all bunched up down in that range. 

As I was explaining it to him, I had a moment of clarity about headroom. Doesn’t matter if all frequencies are present for a big and tall mix, if all the headroom is getting eaten up by everything hitting the same frequencies, the collective volume of that is gonna make everything else feel quieter. 

I usually think of headroom in regard to low end and transients, but it’s true for every part of a mix.

author: Adam Thein
content:
Maybe I can try and distill down some suggestions from the conversation for avoiding the pit of despair while referencing:

1) Don't get stuck going back and forth constantly between your mix and your reference - you can get trapped in a loop

2) Think critically about what elements are in the reference track versus what you are working with - is there enough overlap in production and arrangement that makes this a good reference?

3) Focus on the broad strokes - I've seen it described on the server before as "where the edges are" - how wide is the mix, where's the top end sitting, where's the low end sitting, and what are the elements dominating those frequency spectrums

4) Careful not to shy away from what the track wants to be to make it conform to the bell curve

I'm probably missing a lot of things but here's a start?

author: bobby k
content: a trick i’ve loved in ableton is putting the vocoder before the drum verb and just leaving it on white noise mode. it strips all the tonality out and just mocks up the transients n stuff as white noise, then sending that to a reverb and blending it in with the drum group. creates a nice sizzle on top of stuff but also digs deep enough to feel like a verb reacting to low end from the kick. worth a shot.

author: cian riordan
content: This is a fun trick we discovered in the early days of Saturn. Eric came from tape and he was always cranking the high end on the record side going to tape to account for noise on mix down (easier to tame low end than it is to boost when you're mixing off of tape)... but there was a cool high end sheen that you'd get. So with Saturn, you just separate a high frequency band above what is really audible and just crank the gain on the warm tape setting. Obviously you can adjust to taste, but it's a great way to add a little air & excitement to some dull recordings.

author: cian riordan
content: I literally think of drums/percussion as an upside down triangle… where the bottom point is the low end and the wide top is the high end. As long as the low end is anchored in the middle, I find you can get away with murder with spreading out the mids and highs.

author: Matt Huber
content:
I don’t know how other people do it, but for me the crux of it is that, if both are occupying the sub range, there WILL BE phase cancellation when they are playing the same note. Some notes will be louder and other softer as a result. 

How you want to solve that is up to you. 

You could: 
1. High pass one and let the other rule the low end. Experiment with linear phase vs normal. 

2. Go note by note and ensure that they are phase aligned and working together. This is tedious but the results are GREAT. This is what I do 99% of the time.

content: Expensive to me = timeless. Not chasing trends (blanket of saturation on everything), formidable and clear low end, a robust midrange and a clear top end.

author: cian riordan
content:
My brain:
Subs: 30-60
Low end: 60-250
Low mids: 250-800
Mids: 800-2k
High mids: 2k-6k
High end: 6k-10k
Air: 10k+

author: chrissorem
content: Think about this,  you can only put in  so much low end. So think of mixing as a sleight of hand. If you want more of something and there isn’t more room. Look where you can take  away. It might mean the section before is leaner or it might be that the sub bass gives a little low end to the palm mutes.  Contrast  is what makes things feel bigger or smaller

author: cian riordan
content: In my experience, clubs tend to exaggerate and hype the low end of whatever playing back. If you listen to house music from the 90s, its sounds rather timid by modern standards, but absolutely just slays in a club setting. I find that most contemporary pop mixes have as much low end as humanely possible... and I find it overwhelming in the same settings.

author: cian riordan
content: For DI bass? Skip the unison bullshit and just record in dry. Your mixer will thank you.

author: Calvin Lauber
content: I find soothe can be really good for catching low end resonances. I actually much prefer it for that than using it to tame upper mid/high end stuff like deessing. Sounds sort of weird to me the higher up in the frequency range you go. But awesome on evening out an unruly bass or lower resonances in a vocal

author: BatMeckley
content:
So, got my car back from the shop today and they accidentally fucked up the stereo so that the amp that runs the low end and subs (and back speaker) wasn’t working, so I had to listen to music without basically anything under let’s say 300, and it got me thinking about our conversations about mixing.

I think a lot of the new (and even some of the experienced mixers here) would find out some neat stuff about mixes they like if they brought one into their daw, selected a hyper aggressive low pass (brick wall?) and then scooted it down to say 300 hz. What’s left in the song do you hear? Then down to 200. Down to 100. Down to 26. What exactly is in the low end information of the mixes you enjoy? I’d then flip it to a high pass and go the other way. How much of the bass is above 1k? The kick? I think it would be eye opening for some. 
Shawn Everett once showed me this great mix trick where he low pass something, say a vocal, and slides it all the way down until he can’t hear anything important anymore, and then just switches it from a low pass to a hi pass. (And vice versa). Pretty useful trick to make some space in your mixes.

author: peterlabberton
content: I posted about this years ago, but when tracking, sometimes I’ll mult the kick, send to my Moog Grandmother, roll the filter waaaayy down and crank the resonance up, and then you can really tune where the fundamental is. And you can get really wild exaggerated low end. Phase reverse and see which way hits harder, then tuck it in. I’ve never tried it on snare but I assume it’d work—and I’ve adapted this in the box too with any ol’ eq and some saturation. Fun!

author: cian riordan
content: This ends up being a huge pain IMHO. Individual sessions and bring each finished mix into the next session so you can check the transition if you need to — also useful for reference for trying to keep some consistency with low end, vocal level, etc.

author: chrissorem
content: Tchad Blake Mixing The Black Keys is a great example of this. I don’t remember exactly what he said but he talked about they wanted the drums really vintage sounding but it didn’t hit right until he added that hip hop low end to the drums.

author: chrissorem
content:
It seems like you might be spending to much time in the micro nuances of mixing. (Easy to do that)  try a new approach. Make quick moves and jump to something else, if the kick is too….. it will remind you everytime you listen. Try  to step back and listen to your mixes like a ME. Is there too much or not enough of a certain frequency range?  Then dive back into the micro move adjust and move on. This helps  you stay in the flow and to not get lost  in the weeds.  In my experience the music tells you most of what you need to know. Tempo has a huge effect on how the low end can work. Density often determines how midrange and upper mid/ high freq should work.  The elements in the mix should be serving particular roles and that informs where things should sit and ultimately equal how it makes you feel. I don’t think very much when I mix but I react to what’s in front of me . 
The more you do this the more this will lock in. Another thing that comes to mind, is sometimes if I’m feeling like something isn’t right I’ll do a save as or In your example I’ll mute the kick and duplicate it and start from scratch and see if I can beat it. Sometimes order of operations can lead you down certain paths and as other elements enter the original moves might not being working

author: cian riordan
content: Yes! You’ll find it’ll help with evening out the sustain as well. Rcomp with parallel sans amp is always my starting place for bass guitar.

author: cian riordan
content: I think lots of folks (not you Ross) don't realize how much more low end you can get from things if they're performed/played quieter into a microphone.

author: BatMeckley
content:
As someone who made a living for a while making absurdly loud mixes, I would look at trying to take the low end out of absolutely everything that doesn’t need to be there. Hi passing or shelving almost everything except the kick, and one (or two at most) bass element. And/or sidechain that low end to the primary low end instrument.

Counter intuitively, getting rid of all the bass out of your tracks can actually make your master feel more bass heavy.

It’s wild how much low end garbage is recorded by modern gear, and it just builds up over the entire session. I’d go with the Shawn Everett trick of putting a low pass filter on a track, slide it all the way down until you don’t hear anything useful, and then flip it to a high pass filter.

author: cian riordan
content: @BatMeckley told me he high passes at 1k then RBass-es the low end back in.

author: cian riordan
content: I struggle with the unison concept. It seems like all the worst aspects of digital and analog in one package. Why you wouldn’t record as clean as possible and apply the processing later, with option, baffles me. I get mixes across my desk with all sorts of UAD Bullshit baked in and it’s a drag because I know if it was recorded in flat, there’s be myriad options to make it sound great. The Apollo pres (of all generations) are more than adequate to capture a great bass di performance, just as long as you leave headroom in the recording.

author: cian riordan
content: By this logic, you could argue that any tool in a mixers toolbox is a band aid to a problem created in recording. Compression a bandaid for something recorded too dynamically. HPF a bandaid for something that was incorrectly recorded with too much low end. A Pultec high boost a bandaid for something too dark. Sometimes you get a vocal that has a pokey resonance that happens at 3k and if you try cutting with EQ, it kills the aggressiveness… but if you do it dynamically, it only snags it when the frequency poked 15 dB above where it should.

author: BatMeckley
content: It’s CRAZY how useful the b15 is on bass. The second I finally got one it was like “oh, that’s how a bass sounds”. Love using the plugin too. Whatever it’s doing is all sorts of useful for all sorts of low end instruments

author: Eric Martin
content: I agree with this except I use the PA one, the way the B15 can lay down such a solid low end that sits in a mix for me is what I’m always after, but you absolutely have to play into it because it’s SLOW and requires less notes to sound good IMO.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Think of your mix like Russian nesting dolls - it’s actually 3’mixes in one. The baby version is for tiny speakers - laptop, phone, iPad etc - approximated by a 400 Hz hi pass

Next is your “normal” mix - has low end but like basic car, small stereo, decent TV etc 

And last is the full range - good headphones, club, good car

author: peterlabberton
content: 👋🏻 another fan of high passing most everything besides bass and kick—and often even those elements to zero in on the fundamental, or get a kick to punch right, or make space below a bass gtr for a synth bass, etc.. It’s a habit I’ve formed to make sure I’m giving myself the maximum possible headroom in the low end, especially since I’m primarily working with tracks recorded with microphones, and you can get some wild super sub stuff you’d likely never hear but will clutter things up. And, for low-end elements, I find it can often help focus a sound. Sometimes a kick can sound much punchier and cleaner if you get the filter in the right spot, while retaining or even accentuating the fundamental and punch. Especially if you use a resonant peak on the filter. As far as phase shift… whatever. If it sounds good, it is good! PLUS you can use the phase shift to your advantage to futz with a sound that isn’t 180 degrees out.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Snare, kick, Tom’s, OHs, always cutting around 200-400. All day. 

Boost the absolute fuck out of the fundamental of the snare (anywhere from 100-200hz, tightish Q, +8-16dB)

Find a way to make the high end cool (Saturn 2 distorting above 700hz or so works) 

It’s amazing how much low end a snare mic can have and it just sounds rippin and badass instead of flat and thin. Biggest game changer for my snare sounds

author: cian riordan
content: If it's not low end heavy, then it'll still collapse to mono (who gives a shit), but will effectively operate outside of your speakers.

author: gatewoodsensei
content: Easily my favorite plug-in ever. Slap that ho on an 808? Whew. *chefs kiss*

author: thecoleyoung
content:
Another option here is just simply the performance. Four on the floor is actually really hard to get right, especially under the microscope of a multi mic’d scenario where the low end can vastly change depending on how hard the drummer is hitting. If you hit a kick or snare a little too hard or if the drummer is flamming their kick and snare hits, it can choke the drum, kill the low end, and maybe present itself as being out of phase. But if flipping the phase is solving the issue, I guess it is phase related, which is interesting. 

FWIW, if it is performance related and I know the artist is down for me to be surgical, sometimes I’ll just fly a good hit from the previous bar to replace the one that was flam’d or choked or sounds out of phase. I know this doesn’t work for every scenario, and some drummers might hate that if they found out, but I find that usually does the trick for me and blends in really naturally to a performance.

author: BatMeckley
content: Again, @Zack Hames has a lot of good insight on this. As a general rule, pan hard left and right, compress the snot out of them, take out the low end, and i most of the time prefer them brighter so I can hear them. A side effect of the Melodyne generation is you can actually lock them in too much, and what happens is they start to collapse to mono if they’re too tightly tuned and timed. As with all things, there’s a sweet spot. A fan of throwing a touch of modulation on them too, particularly a LIGHT flange. Then I’ll verb for depth depending on how out front I want the lead to be.

author: cian riordan
content: Little goes a long way. Obviously phasing between the other kick and drum mics will determine how it settles in. I often find out of phase is not always wrong, as it might push the energy into the sub region or the knocks region, which could be useful depending how your low end is sitting. I often use the precision time align plugin because it lets you move a track back and forward in time (I don’t like nudging the actual clips because it’s harder to get back to a starting point if things get fucked up.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I know a lot of folks here have been anti-dynamic EQ in fabfilter, but I genuinely love it for VO and vocals in general. It allows me to balance the low end or low mids without it sounding scooped or too wooly. It balances from word to word, almost like "Soothe" claims, but without being as destructive. I can boost low end without it having a static low end wooliness.

I don't use it for much other than that, sometimes I'll do it for a low end boost on snare with a tight Q. but those have been game changing uses for me.

author: cian riordan
content: Biggest thing I'm doing different is having an entire bus that bypasses the mix bus. I find it useful for enhancing or expanding on the low end.

author: stefanmacc
content: This might be way overboard for your problem haha . But I had this issue on a mix that was sent to me… and what ended up working for me was to basically Re-amp the close mics one at a time into my live room through a speaker. And then lay a snare or kick drum against / on top of said speaker … and re record the decay of the new drum. It sometimes helped to roll off all the high and boost the low end of the shit re amp sound to get the drum to vibrate or move more air … and I was basically able to get real drums played exactly like the original but with the specific tone / decay I wanted. Then I would just blend these new recordings to taste …

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Also, we say "there are no rules" a lot. But actually that's not nuanced enough for my taste (and perhaps, this place).

There are many great "rules." Yes, some are dumb and some are wrong, but many of them are worth learning so you know how to break them.

Things like "cut eq before you compress, boost after" is a really great rule. When you learn to do it and to hear it, you learn why it's so important (pulling low end plosives out of a vocal so it doesn't pin the compressor, for example). From there you learn how and when to break it (I like boosting the 200hz-ish body of a live snare drum into a parallel compressor/ saturator to solidify and have control of that frequency range, automate it for fills, etc.).

IMO this is a great "rule," which is great to learn and then break all the time.

author: Tristan
content:
Bobby, I want to applaud you on your level of self awareness and how much you wrestled and acknowledged your ego on this one - that’s not easy. The only info I noticed missing from your anecdote (not implying it never existed) was if there was a conversation that took place with the artist and producer ahead of time what they felt about the mix as it stood before it came across your desk. This information informs me 99% of the time whether I will mix from their session, add my own thing, start from scratch (rare), etc. 

I’ve had the opinion for a while now that over the next few years it’ll be a repeatably employable trait if you can mix from people’s sessions (including their DAWs). 

I usually find there’s still some good contribution that can be done from us, a bit of cleaning of the low end and some vocal work. It’s kind of fun when you embrace it.

Anyway, overall kudos on this man!

author: Tristan
content:
Repetition, template, predictability = reliable outcomes. 

It’s as much about gain-staging as it is providing QC’d deliverables. Both inform how you work, and you might tweak your template to make your life easier at the end.

Be a minimalist in plugins, use less complicated routing schemes and mixing techniques - go back to basics and implement more creative approaches as needed. Most sessions of pro level mixers will be 80% the same plugin(s) because they know how they react. If something reacts weirdly, or a meter is going unusually berserk and doesn’t match what they expect to hear, it prompts them to interrogate and make changes if need be - I.e. rogue low end rumble smashing a compressor.

No one single person working at a high level I know works exactly the same, but they have some kind of process in place that works for their brain and business. Some more elegant than others.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I would hesitate to get too locked into a console style order.

I’ve got an eq after the comp all the time. I’m more using my pre-eq comp to shape how the compressor responds (if that makes any sense). Ie high passing it to get rid of low end rumble from triggering the comp or handling a spiky resonance that’s mucking about with how the compressor responds.

author: chrissorem
content: A couple days ago I was mixing a song I recorded, it’s a Latin band colabing with a Taiko group all tracked live. Lots of percussion. And an interesting thing happened  that was a first for me.  The verses  felt great the low end is nice and round and then the chorus hit and it didn’t feel right. So I flipped the polarity of the percussion and it locked in. So I automated the polarity between sections.

author: peterlabberton
content: Not sure how helpful this is, but: as I’ve mixed more and more, I think consciously about this less. I tend to try and find 2-3 instruments/vocals that will occupy the main focus of a given song or section, and just put those faders up and try and get them to sound amazing. Then everything else just gets gradually turned up and processed to fit in with or accentuate those primary parts. I’ll often briefly solo them to high pass and usually subtly low pass, then sneak the fader up and not touch any solos again. Getting a track a little too quiet, and then hunting around with Spectre, an API style EQ, or Sie-Q for a pleasing frequency to accentuate works well for finding a spot in the frequency range. Also I will often aggressively scoop out low mids on sampled/software instruments as I find these almost always have way more weight there than needed in even a minimally dense mix. FX may be added at any point along the line: if I know it’ll be integral to the part I’ll pop ‘em on a bit while soloing at first, if not I’ll sneak the effect in gradually with everything else playing. I definitely need to be fairly aggressive with filtering as things get more dense, particularly in the low end.

author: Eric Martin
content:
The LUFS loudness algorithm filters the low end and the top end when calculating, it’s pretty complex math.

IMO I don’t think people are using these EQs so that a meter reads louder but rather that the music sounds better when it’s louder, the distortion artifacts of clipping start building up in that range and it’s hard to build a solid mix that slams and feels good when it’s gummed up in that range.

author: cian riordan
content: Yeah, I’ll usually save HPF for the whole bus, if even… and use shelves to reign in low end on individual mics.

author: Adam Thein
content:
This might be leaving the scope of normal mixing duties but a lot of times if I think the song calls for more consistent low end I'll perform/program a simple sub synth part with a preset I've made on Diva just so I know the sub is going to be always even and then blend it in where it's needed.  I'll sometimes double the same octave or do an octave below.  It's usually way down in the mix but for me it usually gets me where I want to be much faster than trying a plugin, although the only subsynth generator I have is the Brainworx one which is kind of hit or miss for me.  If anyone has a good rec for a subsynth plug I'd love to hear!

Edit: I think this comes in especially handy if you get a track with effects like chorus/phaser/flanger on a subby synth and your subs are shifting everywhere level wise from note to note

author: cian riordan
content: Well from experience, there are certain instruments that take better to additive high-mid saturation -- bass guitars, vocals, etc. Some others -- like certain brass instruments, violins, etc -- can get really harsh if you push those too far. I would start by going heavy handed on the most innocuous of the pile-up and see where that takes you. Saturation is a great way of doing this without making things pokey... but might be good to audition with an EQ first to see what zones you should focus in on. Once you have an idea of where you're going, then you can fire up Saturn 2 or Spectre or Neutron and go to work.

author: Maxim
content:
I’d say when all efforts have been exhausted to try and get stems you’ve only got a few options depending on how “badly” the beat is mixed. But generally my approach might look something like this: First pull down the volume by a bunch. Then usually you’ll want to add in some transients back again. I like Spiff for this to taste. Then sometimes Master Rebalance by Ozone can be a life saver. Especially if say the balance of some instruments are clashing with the vocal or the 808/bass is too loud in relation to everything else. Essentially I’m “unlimiting the beat”. 

Then together with the vocal in the mix I’ll try to shape the beat around the vocal with some subtle (usually reductive) eq moves. Something like dynamically sidechaining a bell on the hihat frequencies to the vocal can help a lot. Or I might also play with Spectral Shape. Some people get good results with sidechaining the vocal as a whole with trackspacer or soothe. Then if I’m missing some super lows or excitement I might throw a Pultec/Bax-type EQ or Spectre on it. 

So ultimately I’m creating as much space as possible and give myself enough headroom to still do some typical mixbus moves.

To me this removes the need to do anything different on the mixbus. Even though it’s likely I won’t be able to push as hard.

author: peterlabberton
content: @Will Melones I’d check out the iZotope Tonal Balance Control meter. My room, with no corrective EQ, gets a little squirrelly below 150-ish, but with some EQ and that plug-in, I’m now able to dial in low end quickly and reliably. It’s pretty easy to see if something is really sticking out—has been clutch for both turning things around super quick on deadlines and also working late/quiet.

author: cian riordan
content: Just stops the compressor from overreacting on the low end material. Very rarely is it better to *not* have some HPF before the comp, even if you’re just snagging subsonic stuff.

author: Ross Fortune
content: Another middle man trying to cut out the low end

author: Calvin Lauber
content: I’m sure the solution is ultimately to chase better monitoring/room treatment. But a good excersize is maybe try pulling up that Kendrick track in your room and listening to the low end, like below 120 and see how that feels in your room against the track your mixing? That kind of thing has helped me learn the response of low end in my imperfect room and given me a better understanding of how it should hit. author: Jesse Ray
content: Skip the subs my friend. I suspect that you’d be skipping the intricate signal chains and tricks as well if you were hearing the low end properly on a bitchin rig

author: cian riordan
content: This has been one of the nice things about the Grace monitor controller... have a numerical value to chase when trying to get consistency at a monitoring level. Start of day usually hits around 65 (~80-85 dBA) then once drums and low end is feeling good, volume comes down to 50 (~70dBA).

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Also, if you’ve already mixed the track, I’d be thinking to make sped up versions of both the source material (played back through your existing chains) AND committed versions of your original BPM tracks. Not to mention your return FX - verb times and predelay might need to be tweaked, possibly delay feedbacks etc. Everything’s going to change, and keeping convincing/good feeling stereo image in things like verbs is one of the challenges.

It’s hard to predict what’s going to happen in any case, so for me it’s about doing the science with your science hat on, taking a break, then fucking around with options until the voodoo clicks. 

It’s not the same mix or even really the same production at the new tempo - groove will change, relationship between rhythmic parts (the satisfying low end you fought for in the kick is suddenly slowing everything down) and consequently vocal parts and their associated time based effects all shifts.

And with all that said: sometimes just blasting your printed mix with soundshifter sync mode beats everything I just described 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: Ross Fortune
content:
~~I can’t remember which track, but ~~I worked on Hot Chip’s Bathful of Ecstacy album (mix assistant). Alexis made some last minute lyric changes, recorded new lead vocals on his iPhone and I had to slot them into a verse. Wildest Pro-Q curves you ever seen, split across a bunch of tracks with different EQ and compressors for each word in some cases. I was pretty happy with the results in the end though, pretty imperceptible after everything went through the vocal mix chain.Took ages but it was a good ear training lesson. 

@jantrit ‘s recipe above is a good methodology

*Went back and dug it out, it was second verse of this track - 1:58 "a lot to learn, a lot to earn" was recorded on iPhone https://open.spotify.com/track/2yhKDrTVMCLBWYd0aIfOfy?si=1a2914797e6843d8

It's got a low double and the FX are such a part of the character; it's a context that allows this tomfoolery.


Incidentally, just remembering some other stuff around that record. It was produced by Philippe Zdar (that particular edit was made less than two weeks before his tragic death), and I remember the stems coming in with all of their character baked in. Wouldn't say it's the band's best album, but some of the parts were awesome.

A bass guitar came in with the hihat baked in to it, so I dutifully went back on emails asking for them separated, but that was how he'd printed it - they were sharing some piece of gear, and for whatever reason that's how they had to go down. Mark Ralph was mixing it, and at the time I might've had a bit of a "huh, Zdar's supposed to be a professional, why is the hi hat on the bass channel" sort of bullshit attitude, but that particular instance cleared that right out. Mark's response to anything like that was always pure acceptance and understanding that people work how they work and it's his job to do what he can with whatever he receives.

author: cian riordan
content:
Couple of random thoughts:
1. If the synth is extremely subby, consider pushing in some midrange via EQ or saturation to help definite it in the mix. Sometimes these synth basses are swimming in sub and the more you turn them up, the more it eats up headroom while still not really being able to hear it.
2. Are you competing against other low end sources outside of the kick? If so, you’ll have to divide and conquer the frequency ranges and let each one live in a specific zone. For example, if you have a bass guitar, make sure that its voiced in the fundamental 200-400hz area and leave the sub handle things below the kick.
3. Utilizing the analyzer in Pro-Q3 can be helpful for finding conflicting frequencies. You can throw Pro-Q3 on say the synth bass and the kick track, then on the synth bass instance, pull up the kick as a secondary histogram in Pro-Q3 and you’ll have a nice visual representation of where the kick is trying to punch through. You can then use some creative cutting to carve room for the kick. Or vice-versa.
4. Sometimes when nothing is working with synth bass and I need to do something drastic, I’ll delay one side of it 30mz to widen it out and get it out of the center. This can fall apart in certain mono-situations, but will often clear way for more bass instruments and the kick drum if done right.

As always, all of this is dependent on everything. YMMV.

author: Moses Mastering
content:
As a mastering engineer, I’ve kept my monitoring level consistent for the past ten years—at a relatively low volume. This isn’t a rule, just my approach, and I do it because I know exactly how a finished track should sound in my room at that level.

Every system has a sweet spot, and if you can identify that in your setup, you’ll get more consistent results. This ties into factors like speaker and amp combinations, how your speakers push air—especially in the low end—and how they perform at different volumes.

Many speakers don’t reproduce low frequencies accurately when played too softly. On the flip side, when pushed too hard, speakers often cap the low end, meaning the bass stops getting louder while the mids and highs continue increasing. This is common in everyday listening setups—people crank their systems beyond their limits, causing an imbalance where the top end dominates.

This is one reason why working with a mastering engineer with a well-calibrated setup can be beneficial. But that doesn’t mean there’s only one way to do things—some engineers work in less-than-ideal setups and still get great results. It all comes down to what works for you and gets you the sound you like.

One thing that’s important to remember which i amsure you already know.... your ears perceive frequencies differently at different volumes—this is a well-documented, non-linear effect. The way we hear balance changes with loudness, which is why understanding how your room and speakers respond at your chosen listening level can make a huge difference in achieving consistent, reliable masters. If you crank it... "memorize" in your ears how it should sound cranked. Then when you drop down to another level.."memorize" how it sounds there. You should then find a few spots you can use.

author: spectrummasters
content: If its any help, fwiw , imo It’s absolutely all about your gain structure and groups, and it’s kind of counter intuitive , you don’t want to be slamming anything ...just very careful db clipped here, db limited there ....across your buses . I have 6 group buses: . Kicks , 808/Bass , Drums , Music, Vox , FX and only clip by 1-2 db at the mixbus . Nothing clips by design or accident anywhere else .....for rnb/hip hop build your mix the Alex tumay / mixed by Ali way , get that 808 up first, on its own ....as loud as you want it , then build everything around it afterwards. Filtering is your friend. Have nothing in the low end but your bass. Overall I’d absolutely suggest watching Jon castelli mixing t Shine (he uses clipping well in there ) and mixed by Ali mixing YG , his mix balance and grouping is CHOICE. I say  somewhere between these two is the perfect rnb/hip hop mix lol . PS. I wouldn’t  do any of that edm/clip to zero stuff, it doesn’t work for anything other than serum madness.

Depending on the tools at your disposal and the exact situation I have a few suggestions:

Look for some low end in the performers vocals. Boosting with SPECTRE is nice but any eq can help add weight to a vocal if you’re boosting correctly. I would suggest having the dynamics tamed to your liking before boosting low end in a vocal because it can easily get out of hand

You could try duplicating the take, use RX de-reverb or whatever you can to remove as much ambience as possible, compress it heavily and blend it in. Obviously compression will bring out ambience so as to not let that become an issue try removing it beforehand.

author: jantrit
content: Never having tried eq match I can’t talk on that but I’ve had good luck doing an ‘eq match’ myself on a number of occasions. Pick the one mic you want to replicate and slap an eq on the other. Listen between both and just use your ears to get as close as you can until it’s not an issue anymore.  More often than not you can get them close enough that no one will be able to tell. Start with broad strokes “this one has more low end” boom add some low to the other. Then slowly starting to narrow in making smaller and smaller adjustments until it feels right.

author: Brian Reynolds
content: I made it up. Take a synth for example. Set up a parallel send bus. Put the panner on the send. I usually compress it to smithereens. Blend it in underneath the main signal. Or there are more adventurous circular 3D panning options that I find work well top end arps or vox chops. It was an idea born out of how people use 1/8 ping pong delays to fill out behind Bass guitar. Basically a different way to have the audio swim around subtly behind the main source. Try it. It's fun

author: Maxim
content:
I think that might be a limiting factor on top of the artists' abilities (Pop Smoke already sounded dope before his setup got professional https://youtu.be/317TP4JOSSE). I've recorded not-so-great rappers through nice chains and mixing wasn't the answer to save a (lacking) source. It never gave you *that* feeling. But even if you are recording great rappers cheaper mics tend to lack body and rarely have "boostable" or pleasant top end as you said. So it's a bit complicated before you even get to "mixing". Felt that was important to mention so you're not too hard on yourself.

But assuming that the limiting factor really is just mixing there's a bunch of options. First things first: is your monitoring and listening environment decent? Or are you on headphones? This could make placing vocals even harder for you. 

Then do you have a process that starts with vocal cleanup to get rid of or reduce unappealing harshness or performance issues? Despite being simple, people tend to skip basic tools like clip-gain to even out a performance. This should usually also give you some leeway for strategic boosts. Maybe instead of EQ look at harmonics. Fresh Air by Slate is free. Gem Dopamine is nice. Spectre is great. All of these should give you that "sizzle" you might be missing.

Then to get the presence and even out the performance you could try some parallel compression with something like an 1176. Also, try out Multiband Compression with the Mcdsp 404 or C6 or whatever you have to control the performance throughout the song once you've got a vocal sound you like.

I also find mixing the 808 & drums together with the vocal the most useful when it comes to gain staging and getting the song to feel right.

Obviously, there's more that could be said but I find processes more helpful than tools. It's art at the end of the day. Attached what Serban's assistant sees as their/his "mixing process". Mix more and experiment with what you have. Get feedback from the artists.

author: Deleted User
content:
1. Corrective EQ in the Upper midrange/high end, notching out all the harsh resonances, taming the pick transients if the bass is played with a pick. I love the way MAAT Santa Cruz does this ever so smoothly. 
2. I compress the bass with a compressor sidechained to a LPF(!), to get some low end body which is usually severely lacking. The LPF is set between 1000-2000 hz, attack 0-8 ms and release 200-400 ms depending on the tempo of the song/bass part. Reducing 3-5 dB on peaks. This gets me really far.
3. If the bass is a shortscale, I’ll use Goodhertz Tiltshift to move the low mids from around 200 hz to around 100 hz, out of the way of the guitars. 
4. Then I put an amp emulation on the channel. Whichever one floats your boat. Plugin Alliance B15, Guitar Rig, TSE BOD, whatever. I’ll be boosting low end and cutting high end here, or before with a separate instance of Tiltshift. 
5. If I want the bass to sound „rock“ and cut, I send it to a parallel distortion, which can be anything. I like TSE BOD, which is another sansamp copy which  has a lot of sub. My trick here is to add a clipper before the sansamp to really get extra gnarl. Logic‘s stock Bitcrusher works great, but I’m sure anything works.

author: Adam Thein

My two gotos are 

A) duplicate the track and pitch down an octave (Ableton), eq the hell out of it to fit, check phase against OG

B) perform/program a sub bass synth track that doubles the part exactly.  If you aren't a keyboardist maybe using Melodyne to extract midi or another audio-to-midi function

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Also probably worth saying that once you’ve got the part down, print both layers (soft or hard synth), as the phasing between each synth’s own oscillators can radically affect things (especially in the low end).

The relationship between the two layers will further exacerbate this (hence @Adam Thein ‘s comment re checking summed bass phase against each kick hit)

author: Ross Fortune
content:
What does floppy kick mean?

I had good luck with Smack Attack recently on a kick with excessively long low end that hung around after the hit.

Pushing the attack and lowering the overall gain in smack attack worked in that instance, but probably more important was high passing the drum bus so all the flubby stuff sub ~40/50Hz was minimised. I think the filter was somewhere around 60, probably at 12dB per octave. Might sound high in isolation, but it sat well with the bass.

This is over simplified but.
If you want “loud 808s” it’s all about levelling everything around it. Clipping your drums for a “loud” impact but low peak level.

author: Eric Martin
content:
transformers add harmonics, you could call that “smearing” because it spreads the audible frequencies out across multiple octaves.

Try putting a sustain 808 into a Neve preamp, you’ll hear the distortion that the Neve is adding to everything it’s used on, most of the time you can’t “hear” it but it’s happening.

Consider this, when a record was recorded to tape in the past, it hit the console then the tape, then when it was mixed, the tape went out and hit that same console again, further adding more harmonics.

JC is accomplish that sound through clippers, peak limiters, and transient designers, while allowing the low frequencies to get through which tape wouldn’t allow, best of both worlds

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I’ve got some ideas for you. 
1) if your gain staging is done properly, you’ll notice when the low end starts to interact negatively with the rest of the frequency bands. 
2) reference reference reference. Listen to songs with the kind of low-end you’re looking for and reference them diligently.
3) have someone you trust that can tell you how it’s going when you think you’re getting close. I got a road rig together for mixing, expecting that I’d get 70% there before finishing in my studio. Surprisingly I got closer to 95% just using good techniques ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ 
4) its like anything else, the more you do it, the better you get at it. 

I hope this helps. Andrew Scheps is on headphones now and he seems to be real happy. You might be able to find some good insight from him.

Also keep in mind I do mostly Country Music and bedroom pop, which aren’t necessarily the most bass heavy genres.

author: Deleted User
content:
I love midrange mess. 

having good amount of midrange to poke out is the right idea. It just needs to be distributed in a way that makes sense to our ears. 

Low and high end lacking could mean that there’s actually not enough of them, but it could also mean that the midrange isn’t distributed in a way that lets the low end be pushing the speakers and be able to hear the top end *distinctively. 

In terms of midrange distribution, I found it helpful to think about “where do I want this instrument to occupy in the mids?” -> to do this, context is absolutely necessary. I’m not a mixer, but I like to produce with that in mind, and once I get to the mixing process then I listen to the whole thing and start thinking about where I want to put things. 

and then there is this new thing I’m starting to find and explore- “what instruments want to push the speakers together in xHz area?” 

sometimes boosting the same area in two different elements that hit simultaneously help tighten things up and glue things together, rather than everything moving front and back all over the place. 

I used to think everything has to be separated like a jigsaw puzzle, but I’m only starting to realize that not how audio works. these days I’m learning that some things will want to occupy the presence in the same or similar area, and that is the thing that helps the mixes feel more coherent sometimes.

author: Sam Segarra

Essentially medium to high ratio, fast attack, medium to fast relesse and, importantly, cutting a good amount of low end in the sidechain so compression is only triggered by the transients. Any compressor plugin with a fast attack and a comprehensive sidechain should work.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Warmth

Alters the frequency-dependant characteristics of the limiter’s detector circuit.

A big part of Faraday Limiter’s thick, punchy sound is its frequency-dependent gain reduction. Low and high frequency sounds hit the limiter differently, and — depending on the Warmth setting — will exhibit different attack/release characteristics. High values, such as 100%, generally sound thicker and punchier, while low values, like -100%, have a quick, bright limiter sound.

For example, you can often use the warmth control to emphasize different aspects of a snare drum: more Warmth gives more thud & low end; less Warmth gives more stick & snare presence.

The Warmth control is not EQ, and will not change the frequency response of the plugin.

author: Slow Hand
content:
The first thing that comes to mind is that you may be pushing into your master buss limiter too hard. 

How much gain reduction is your limiter currently doing? If you're already pushing aggressively into your limiter and then you're boosting low end *into* it, it's going to keep turning it back down.

If that's what's happening, the answer would be to back off your limiter so that the low end doesn't get compressed.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Totally. 

Don’t be afraid to carve a *whole* lot of low end out of your verb with a HPF. I like a gentle slope -  6dB/octave - and that lets me put the center freq even higher while still sounding “natural”.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I tried that. I did see a *little* bit of variation, but it was subtle. Here are the two big observations:
### Subtle and Warm Mode
@ -0.03 input level, the harmonic bloom diminishes in amplitude as I sweep my test tone from 30 Hz (complex bloom) up to 4 kHz (totally gone). So it seems that the transfer curve is biased to break up in the low end sooner and you have to drive it *way* harder to get bloom after 2kHz.
### Warm Mode only
The 1st order harmonic seems to gradually drop 6dB in amplitude as I sweep my test tone from 30 Hz up to 1.8 kHz. It's still present after that, but it stops dropping in amplitude.

author: Slow Hand
content: It sounds like your 808 is hitting your limiter too hard. Because the limiter has to turn down the entire mix each time that it hits the threshold, all of the music and vocals are being reduced in volume, or "ducked", while the 808 is playing.

author: Slow Hand
content: The solution will be to improve your gain-staging. For starters, it sound like your 808 needs to be turned down. If doing that makes the 808 feel too quiet relative to the rest of the instruments then you will need to find a way to turn down the level of the entire mix going into the limiter so that the limiter is not doing such extreme gain reduction each time the 808 hits. There are other ways to achieve loudness besides smashing the limiter. Let me see if I can find a good summary in the show notes.

And right is the same 808 with saturation added in a more thoughtful manner (in parallel just adding upper harmonics that sound better to me).

author: Eric Martin
content:
right, there was a spectral shaper on low mids on one of his buses, but then again on the mix bus it was doing the 1-6k.

I think from what I understand that JC is doing he is controlling the attack so it’s consistent, then using the transient shaper to make sure it’s the same for every hit. It is smart, and for his workflow it’s also fast and easy.

I use compressors a lot, but I’m also working in mostly indie rock with acoustic drums and bass guitars not 808’s and drum machines, which is a drastically different world. I also think I’m doing what most people don’t do and I don’t always love the artifacts of compression so I generally use slow attacks to maintain transients and fast releases to recover quickly (I adjust so that I get the fastest release before audible distortion)

BTW Bruce Swedien while he may have evangelized not using compression don’t underestimate that his greatest works were done to tape and even when you were conservative and didn’t hit tape hard, the transformers going into tape and out of and the tape as a medium itself would peak limit attack heavy instruments like drums

I also find i use the neves transformers if ive got a phase issue between two parrallels, if i send one through the neve it can often shift the phase in one a bit and they blend better when they sum back after. author: NoahNeedleman
content:
High passing the vocals right below the fundamental shouldn’t kill any low end thickness- if anything it’ll give you a little hump there. 

There are a lot of compressors that add low end resonance, some more musical than others. UAD 175-B and Fairchild do really well with that for my taste.

author: Adam Thein
content: To expand on this idea, I’ve also had good luck with making a sine wave with a pitch envelope similar to like an 808 or more of an edm kick and start with it tuned to the kick drum fundamental and pitch downward - I haven’t had a ton of luck personally with using the tuning of the key of the song cause it becomes pretty boomy.  Also I’ve had good luck taking that pitch envelope sine or triangle and throwing a volume shaper (I use Devious Machines Duck) and sidechain that to the kick in mic, play with the shape so that it doesn’t interact with the transient, or print the whole thing to audio and play around with the timing so your sub is slightly behind the beat so your kick transient can still remain clear and your sub can bloom behind the transient.  Depends a lot on what your bass instruments are doing also but something to try!

author: Deleted User
content:
I’m ruling out the performance since you said it is smooth- but great bass guitar performance often don’t need much clip gain because good players know how to adjust their touch to the acoustic properties of the instrument.

Sometimes it’s arrangement, when instruments are playing notes that aren’t really meaningful to the arrangement then it won’t cut through the mix. Or if the other instruments are doing things that aren’t meaningful to the arrangement, it can get contribute to bass notes getting lost as well. 
Try muting other stuff one at a time until you can hear the bass well, and evaluate why the bass isn’t cutting through. 

Sometimes, you just gotta zoom out and mute the bass and mix the song without the bass and put it in. Before you do this, save as and solo vocals (if there is any) bass and drums (sometimes one other most important/prominent element in the arrangement on top of that) and make that work first. You can get it to a point of making the mix work this way if there is one element that just doesn’t sit well in the mix.

author: spectrummasters
content: Along with others suggestions , I would advise some easy quick  tools to help you diagnose  . Izotope insight has a very good spectrograph that clearly reveals what’s happening down at 20-30 hz and how much energy is there . We ve also discussed izotope tonal balance here as well , but it’s really a very handy diagnostic when used to investigate where your low end energy is against a referenced track you like . Izotope Match eq is another tool that again allows you to compare and contrast what’s happening in your low end . I’ve also found the Shawn Everett trick mentioned here , useful for investigating low end (put a brick wall low pass filter on your mixbus and sweep it down to the 20-30hz with your subs on and see what that actually sounds and feels like . The other thing I find helpful is my gain staging and buses are set up so that I know how much gr and level should be arriving at each bus , so you soon know if you’re too hot just by looking at the comp / limiter . The last thing I’d say is know your speakers . I apply all this to myself because translation is my main point of focus right now . I forget where I heard it said , but I heard it said that the listener hears the inverse of what we the mixers hear .

author: jantrit
content:
Drums - dark red 
Bass - blue
Sub bass - dark blue
Piano - blue
Keys like rhodes - light blue
Synths and organ - turquoise 
Guitars  - green
Strings - green for violins/ violas and then blue as you get to cello and basses
Vocals - yellow
Doubles - darker yellow
Bvs - various shades of orange and brown
Rooms and reverbs- purple
Perc, samples and sound effecty stuff - pink
Horns - depends sometimes green sometimes yellow

Auxs are the standard protools colour, master same thing. Print track is tape brown 😆

Always start with drums, overs than kick/ snare then rooms. Bass comes next, then through rest of the rhythm  section to any other instrumentation. Then vocals and finally bvs

Auxiliaries all somewhere in the middle usually after bass or keys/ guitar. Then print track and master.

author: spectrummasters
content:
....aw, found the old explanation of why....re: vu meter before the limiter and lufs after. 
This of course will be elementary stuff for everyone in here ...but might as well leave it here for a reminder/refresher. 

1. The VU meter to highlight how the mix is behaving pre-limiter :
VU (Volume Unit) Meters essentially display an average of what we hear, rather than the very fast peaks that we don’t. they will show you the energy in the low end, and if there is radical movement, then you probably have an issue with frequencies that you aren’t hearing.VU meters should “dance” smoothly and in a gentle manner, usually in time with the music, rather than in big jumps and erratic, out of time movement.  This erratic movement implies that there are drastic level changes, which will be hard to control in mastering and need addressing in the mix.  

2. The LUFS meter post limiter to set your loudness levels

Personally, i dont use this MO ...i like izotope tonal balance to monitor the mix but....just wanted to share what i rememmbered about people using vu ITB

author: stefandurandt
content: I use an Analog VU meter on the output of my monitor controller built by the inhouse tech who also worked at Neve (he designed and built the 8816 summing box) - he recommended the Sifam ones because their ballistics are really good - which I think is the main argument for analog vs digital. I started using them itb after Leon Zervos who masters at 301 where I work but used to work at Sterling (where he mastered classics like mambo nr 5, the macarena, Avril Lavigne, Maroon 5 etc.) recommended them & spoke about the same “dancing” thing that @spectrummasters spoke about. After that I also got another 2  lessons by 301 mastering engineers (one who’s won like 19 aria - australian grammies & been nominated for like 90) - once where I gave a floortom too much bottom end $ & that really triggered a mastering compressor limiting him in some way & he showed me how the left side jumped on the vu - I didn’t hear it at all in the mixing room but could hear it clearly in the mastering room. The other engineer showed me the same thing this time with a powerful lead vocal. This was kinda back when the loudness wars were still a bit more relevant & when I delivered quiter mixes & left them more space to do their thing & these energy bursts limited the final loudness potential. Then I saw that same Jacquire King thing & together all this made me think of how useful the VU is if you’re working in less than ideal bass monitoring environment - it really shows the bass energy in a pretty unique way. I like listening to references (check the bass VU on for instance Jon Castelli’s Khalid Talk vs Sza Low - one very kick focused & one super sub focussed - both a fuckton of low end vs Serban Blinding Lights try -7 as the reference - BL hovers around 0 & is louder lufs wise & then try Fleetwood Mac Dreams (I think the 2012 remaster) - softer, nice transients, beautiful bass - being driven by Kick,snare & bass) - all of those “dance” with the groove.

author: Will Melones
content: I’ve had this with the relationship between kick in and overheads. It *looks* like the waveforms are opposing each other. And it makes sense—air pressure is pushed toward the kick in mic while it’s moving away from the overheads. But flipping the polarity sucks out all the low end. Sometimes that big bump at the beginning of the waveform may not be what you’re hearing as the fundamental. Just gotta trust your ears over your eyes. And air *isn’t* just moving away from the overheads, because the lowest frequencies are exploding outward in every direction, up and back into those mics as well.

author: Adam Thein
content:
I don't do a ton of referencing while mixing anymore but it definitely was and still is a key for learning new things.

I mostly work with young indie artists and producers who are still finding their sound and it's very common for me to get notes like "can we make the guitar solo sound like XYZ song from ABC artist," and usually after a little bit of frustration I work my way through to a new trick up my sleeve by dissecting a sound and trying to recreate it.

I think the major pitfall to avoid though for mixers and producers just at the beginning is understanding that you can't squeeze blood from a stone - not getting discouraged or into the pit of despair if your bedroom produced track with amp sims and samples isn't standing up against the big budget Studio A level records.  But that doesn't mean you can't start learning what a great bass tone is in a mix and why it's working by listening to those intently.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So think of mid vs side in terms of panning left right & center, and think of EQ as volume. 

If you’ve got a lot of low end information on the sides, and say it’s fighting with a mono bass track that’s supposed to be holding down the majority of the low end, you can eq the lows out of those panned tracks, or you can blanket turn all the lows down on the sides with a m/s eq on a buss, so that the L and R info is quieter. It’s basically a group volume ride for frequencies instead of tracks. You can also do this on individual stereo tracks if just panning isn’t granular enough. 

The why & when is mostly about taste. I tend to mix into a proQ3 setting that has the sides hi passed around 100 for the same reason I have a pultec boosting highs & lows on the master- it just ends up doing a lot of work for me.

It can become problematic if I’ve got big toms in a song and, after I’ve got a mix starting to cook I’ll toggle it on & off to see if I’m doing more harm than good. For the kind of music I mostly do, it works more often than not, but the one song I sent to Cian for mixing he basically blasted me for doing that. (In his own kind and gentle way.)

But m/s eq isn’t just for the master buss. You can think about it for any stereo track. Sometimes, I have an acoustic that’s carrying the whole song, but the fundamentals are fighting with the vocal, so I’ll turn the mid down at that frequency (or side chain that to the vocal if it feels anemic when the vocal is out.) that leaves the sides as big as you like cause it’s not fighting with my mono vocal.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Seeing a few people tagging me asking for more deets. I’m on holiday with fam now so a little write up will need to suffice. 

Jack’s video covered a good chunk of what I’m doing. Attenuating a few frequency hotspots and clicks is more than half of it. Unlike Jack, I use mouth declick far more than spectral repair or declick. 

There’s other things I’m doing as well but they vary from song to song. I’ll manually smooth out plosives, mic stand bumps, clothing rustles etc. I’ve even gone through and reduced the aliasing in a processed vocal (which takes fucking forever to lasso tool). 

One thing I’ve never seen anyone mention before is fades in RX. It’s a little hard to explain so I’d have to make a video for this, but I do frequency dependent fading. If you think about it, almost all sounds decay with the high end decaying faster than the low end, so when I’m fading noise floor I do the same and the result is more natural and invisible.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Great, we’ve all kind of known that. Back to FFT, which works in a LINEAR  way. If we run a 16 “band” FFT on a 48 kHz signal it will divide the audio spectrum (0 Hz to 24 kHz) into 16 evenly spaced bins or bands. Each bin is 1500 Hz wide. Think about that for a second. That means we have a a single bin that contains everything from 16500 to 18000 Hz, a very “narrow” slice as it pertains to musical interest. On the flip side we are left with only a single bin that represents everything from 0 Hz to 1500 Hz, a huge chunk of the music. If the whole point was to slice up this signal so we could do something interesting to it then that is often not the resolution we hoped for. 

I see the hands going up!! “Let’s just increase the number of bands to get more frequency resolution”. And herein lies one of the confounding things about FFT. We are caught in a frequency domain/time domain tradeoff. The finer the bands or slices the more things blur in the time domain when we reconstitute via the iFFT (of the bands we have processed any or all bands). If no processing then you can run any length FFT and then the iFFT and perfectly reconstruct the original signal. (This is what you’ll often see 16 to 48k FFT on signal meters).

So some practical examples to help you guys get a handle on this. Open a file in RX and get the spectral repair module in attenuate mode set to a strength of 1. Set bands to the lowest possible (128?), figure out how wide your bins are. Now try to do a detailed edit in the low end, you’ll notice that you don’t have much “resolution”, but up high say above 10k it’s razor sharp. Now bump up your bands to the max 4096. Do the same LF edit and you’ll suddenly have nice narrow frequency slices but you’ll see things getting very blurry in the time domain, tight kicks become smeary whooshes

author: spectrummasters
content: ...im aiming for the dynamic range between the moments where the kick and bass hit seperately...to when they hit together....to be my low end dynamic overall (if that makes sense)....so i dont want to flatten that range there....and instead prefer to compress the kick and bass seprately on their own buses . Im using parrallels of my kick and bass to get my loudness and harmonics, pre Low End Bus . If id want more control id consider a hz-dependent side chain on the bass from the kick, but dont like how that f's with the attack of the bass. Trying to do less processing at all stages......and get there with better balancing ..... So...a tiny bit of  comp on the kick and bass buses (0.5 db slow attack, fast release...usually neutron comp) and only an eq and standard clip on the kick bass bus to only catch random peaks and not jam the final  limiter . i like a littler expansion also , playing around with the pro G expnasion mode is fun

author: Rob Domos
content:
1) I know exactly what you’re talking about. For me, a couple things have helped 

- try shelving the lows rather than use a HPF. I’ll even cascade a couple of shelves sometimes if I have to go crazy, or shelve 150 and HP 50. You can get similar amounts of attenuation and the shape of the phase rotation feels a little less fake.

- how much of this are you doing in solo? Often the phase fuckery bothers me in solo and doesn’t as soon as the 808 is bumping. 

- sometimes I just let the lowend be loose and say “fuck it. My mix, my aesthetic choice”. Seems like not many agree but I like lowend in my vocal.

content: i've dealt with this a fair amount, but never thought to mention it here. For better or worse, I often end up with pretty air-tight first passes on the gainstaiging front. So sometimes, when a mix note is as simple as "turn up 808", the rest of the mix changes for obvious reasons. I'm hitting my multiband different, hitting my clipper different, hitting my limiter different; so if I were to simply execute that note, now the vocal, guitar, pretty much everything shifts a good bit in energy and I then spend time making the mix work again now that a big chunk of energy got pushed up in it. (side note - I like to mix a bit more gentle/tight on the low-end side since the lows are so hot in car systems, headphones, entertainment centers, etc. these days. Midrange is my home base.) Curious what your experiences have been with this sort of thing, and/or if you have recommendations.

author: Adam Thein
content:
All good it’s a little tricky at first and just really difficult to explain typed out for me.

Same concept as using a sidechain input from a kick drum to duck the 808 - an external sidechain allows us to give the compressor something to listen to and apply the compression from that source to another source.  When the kick is fed to a compressor on your 808 channel - the compressor “listens” to the kick and applies the compression curve from the kick onto the bass.

So in your case of printing stems with a mix bus compressor - you want the SPL Iron plugin to “listen” to the entire mix as it heard it before but then apply that compression to one track at a time.

We can do this in Ableton with some clever workarounds, which would be a lot more efficient to show you on a video call on the server if you are free later.  Essentially you need to print a version of your song at each point in your mix bus chain where there are dynamics plugins (just before the Slate plugin, just before the Iron Compressor but after all the other plugins) and then send that audio to those corresponding plugins’ external sidechain inputs and then you can use the “include return and master effects” and get the result you are looking for

Some bass guitars kind of have this phenomenon, where even when they play an open E which should be 41Hz, you hear the harmonic more clearly at 82Hz

author: JustinLeu
content:
You could achieve the same numerical amount either way (no HPF or with HPF), the threshold would be different....but the same amount of compression is possible. 

What would be VERY different is how the compressed signal "feels" 

Think about what would happen if you keyed (side-chained) your mixbus compressor with the bass guitar vs if you keyed the compressor with just the snare drum. Given the same attack/release settings the entire mix would move differently.

content:
Conceivably any vocoder would be sufficient because the harmonic richness depends on the carrier signal you feed into it, which could easily be any bright synth that you have on hand.

That said, even if you have a darker carrier signal you can usually “tilt” the vocoder bands towards more high end energy and less low end if you want it brighter.

Have you tried Izotope’s *Vocal Synth 2*? It has lots of vocoder-adjacent effects that will do similar things.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Oh interesting - For some reason my journey has led to me only reaching for the CLA76 on a parallel for the bass, but I should try it again in other contexts.

In case anyone would wanna try my approach to getting bass to play nice across more speakers / phones:

- I use the 20 ratio bluey to squash a bass parallel. Then I drive it through the free TSC 808 plugin for further emphasize the harmonics the bluey brings out. (EQ too)
- Then, I use Audreio on the master to play the mix through my phone instead of my monitors. Once on the phone, you can blend the parallel with the bass in a way where there’s little to no audible difference on a monitor, but the illusion of a bass can be heard through the harmonics playing on the phone.
- It’s a balancing act, but there’s almost always a nice sweet spot to be found where it doesn’t change the quality of the sound enough to be intrusively perceived on HD speakers, while giving life to the bass on lesser speakers.

This has helped my bass translate to more systems, and is the only time I find myself wanting to use the CLA76.

author: spookydrums
content: I feel like I get bass instruments with strong first and second harmonics, and also floor toms, a lot. I ususally dip a little in that frequency range and if it's a bass guitar what works for me to make it cut through more a lot of the time is Soundtoys Sie-Q with a healthy boost (think at around 3 o'clock) at 1.5 kHz. Oh, and SansAmp (the Audiopunks one is really good) can work wonders, either in-line or in parallell.

content:
Have a bit of situation here that I’m not sure how to navigate on a song where I am producing and mixing

Currently on mix 51 of a song (which is not a problem in and of itself) and suddenly the artist says “I want everything under 150hz mono bc a famous EDM producer said so” 

Mind you the song is not EDM in any way shape or form also the feedback seems to be purely based on visual information he gets from some sort of stereo analyzer not something that actually bothers him when listening

Now the mix/production was not built in any way to be mono sub 150hz so there’s quite a bit more information there than on a typical EDM bc I tend not to surgically remove everything sub 100-150hz. So you get some of that in the keys, synths, guitars etc

I know it’s “flip the burger” etc but I was wondering if y’all had any advice on how to approach this

Don’t wanna argue with the artist ofc but just going and removing everything sub 150 seems like not a great idea so I figured might focus only on the bass instruments (which is really just an electric bass with a lot of low end) and try to make that as mono as possible

Any other advice?
